factoid: Voices in the crowd were heard saying “Oh yes, an artful tale!”.
Voices in the crowd were heard saying “Follow her into slavery!”.
Voices in the crowd were heard saying “Pull down your houses and go into bondage!”.
Voices in the crowd were heard saying “I dare say!”.
Voices in the crowd were heard saying “I’ll give you grain, indeed!”.
Princess Mary left the crowd with a drooping head.
Princess Mary went back to the house.
Princess Mary repeated her order to Dron to have horses ready for her departure next morning.
Princess Mary went to her room.
Princess Mary remained alone with her own thoughts.
Princess Mary sat by the open window of her room for a long time that night.
Princess Mary heard the sound of peasants’ voices from the village.
Princess Mary was not thinking about the peasants.
Princess Mary felt she could not understand the peasants no matter how much she thought about them.
Princess Mary thought only of her sorrow.
Princess Mary's sorrow seemed to belong to the past after the break caused by cares for the present.
Princess Mary could remember her sorrow and weep or pray.
After sunset the wind had dropped.
The night was calm and fresh.
Toward midnight voices began to subside.
A cock crowed toward midnight.
The full moon began to show from behind the lime trees.
A fresh white dewy mist began to rise.
Stillness reigned over the village and the house.
Pictures of Princess Mary's father's illness and last moments rose one after another to Princess Mary's memory.
Princess Mary lingered over these images with mournful pleasure.
Princess Mary repelled the picture of Princess Mary's father's death with horror.
Princess Mary could not contemplate the picture of Princess Mary's father's death even in imagination at that hour.
The pictures presented themselves to Princess Mary so clearly and in such detail that they seemed present, past, and future.
Princess Mary vividly recalled the moment Princess Mary's father had his first stroke.
Princess Mary recalled Princess Mary's father being dragged along by his armpits through the garden at Bald Hills.
Princess Mary recalled Princess Mary's father muttering something with his helpless tongue.
Princess Mary recalled Princess Mary's father twitching his gray eyebrows.
Princess Mary recalled Princess Mary's father looking uneasily and timidly at her.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father wanted to tell her what he told her the day he died.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father had always thought what he said then.
Princess Mary recalled in detail the night at Bald Hills before Princess Mary's father had his last stroke.
Princess Mary remained at home against Princess Mary's father's will that night.
Princess Mary did not sleep that night.
Princess Mary stole downstairs on tiptoe that night.
Princess Mary went to the door of the conservatory where Princess Mary's father slept that night.
Princess Mary listened at the door.
Princess Mary's father was speaking to Tíkhon in a suffering and weary voice.
Princess Mary's father spoke of the Crimea and its warm nights.
Princess Mary's father spoke of the Empress.
Princess Mary's father wanted to talk.
Princess Mary wondered why Princess Mary's father did not call her.
Princess Mary wondered why Princess Mary's father did not let her be there instead of Tíkhon.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father would never tell anyone what he had in his soul.
Princess Mary thought that that moment would never return for Princess Mary's father or for her.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father might have said all he longed to say, and that she might have heard and understood him.
Princess Mary wondered why she did not enter the room.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father would then have said to her what he said the day he died.
Princess Mary's father was talking to Tíkhon.
Princess Mary's father asked Tíkhon about Princess Mary twice.
Princess Mary's father wanted to see Princess Mary.
Princess Mary was standing close by outside the door.
It was sad and painful for Princess Mary's father to talk to Tíkhon who did not understand him.
Princess Mary remembered Princess Mary's father began speaking to Tíkhon about Lise as if she were alive.
Princess Mary's father had forgotten that Lise was dead.
Tíkhon reminded Princess Mary's father that Lise was no more.
Princess Mary's father shouted “Fool!” at Tíkhon.
Princess Mary's father was greatly depressed.
From behind the door Princess Mary heard Princess Mary's father lay down on his bed groaning.
Princess Mary's father loudly exclaimed “My God!”.
Princess Mary wondered why she did not go in then.
Princess Mary wondered what Princess Mary's father could have done to her.
Princess Mary wondered what she could have lost.
Princess Mary thought that Princess Mary's father would then have been comforted and would have said that word to her.
Princess Mary uttered the caressing word Princess Mary's father had said to her on the day of his death.
Princess Mary repeated “Dear-est!”.
Princess Mary began sobbing.
Princess Mary's tears relieved her soul.
Princess Mary saw Princess Mary's father's face before her.
Princess Mary saw a timid, feeble face she had not known before.
Princess Mary had seen this face for the first time quite closely when she stooped near her father's mouth to catch what he said.
The face had all its wrinkles and details.
Princess Mary repeated “Dear-est!” again.
